data.title: Princess Beatrice
data.meta_description: Princess Beatrice Mary Victoria Theodora of the United Kingdom (1857-1944) is the youngest of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert's nine children. Beatrice was praised for her long, golden hair in her youth. Like most of her siblings, she had blue eyes and pale skin. Beatrice liked to impersonate...
data.text:
Princess Beatrice Mary Victoria Theodora of the United Kingdom (1857-1944) is the youngest of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert's nine children.

Appearance[]

Beatrice was praised for her long, golden hair in her youth. Like most of her siblings, she had blue eyes and pale skin.

Personality[]

Beatrice liked to impersonate her mother and her courtiers and had a good sense of humour. She was very loyal to her mother and served as her secretary and companion for her entire life.

History[]

Childhood[]

Beatrice was born in 1857 as the youngest of the nine royal children. She was born shortly before her elder sister Vicky married.

When she was four years old, her father died and her mother was consumed by grief. She replaced her father as her mother's closest confidente . Despite being the youngest of nine, she grew up quite lonely.

The sibling closest to her in age, Leo, was kept apart because of his haemophilia and raised along with their brother Arthur, mainly abroad, making her closest sibling in age Louise, who was nine years older. Her eldest sisters were already married by the time she became a teenager.

Beatrice assisted her mother in everyday life until her death in 1901.

Marriage[]

Victoria lost her elder daughters (Vicky and Alice) to foreign husbands and therefore didn't want to lose any other children to foreign politics, especially Beatrice "Baby".

Beatrice secretly got engaged to Henry Mountbatten, a military from Germany. Victoria didn't talk to her daughter for a year because of the secret engagement. Baby was eventually forgiven and married Henry in 1885. They had four children:

Alexander Albert (1886)

Victoria Eugenie Julia Ena (1887)

Leopold Arthur Louis (1889)

Maurice Victor Donald (1891)

Henry tragically died in 1896 in Sierra Leone when their son was just 4, the same age Beatrice had been when losing her father. She lost her two youngest sons at an early age due to haemophilia and in the First World War.

When her mother died, Beatrice edited all of her diaries and published them, while destroying most of it. She wasn't well-liked by her brother, the King, because she reminded him of their mother.

Trivia[]
